docs.title: Harness CLI Manual
docs.text:
Harness CLI (hc) is a command-line interface tool for interacting with Harness services.

hc [<global-flags>] <command> <subcommand> [<positional-args>…] [<flags>]

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Available commands - Auto-generated command reference
  • Usage examples - Practical examples and workflows
  • Documentation guide - How to maintain docs
  • Installation guide

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: You can find detailed installation instructions in the main README.

docs.title: Quick Install
docs.text:
Install the latest version with a single command:

curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/harness/harness-cli/v2/install | sh

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/harness/harness-cli.git
cd harness-cli
make build

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Run hc auth login to authenticate with your Harness account. Alternatively, hc will respect the following environment variables:

  • HARNESS_API_URL - Base URL for the Harness API
  • HARNESS_API_KEY - Authentication token
  • HARNESS_ORG_ID - Organization ID
  • HARNESS_PROJECT_ID - Project ID
hc auth login

The authentication credentials are stored in $HOME/.harness/auth.json.

docs.title: Global Flags
docs.text:
All commands support the following global flags:

--account string          Account ID (overrides saved config)
--api-url string          Base URL for the API (overrides saved config)
--token string            Authentication token (overrides saved config)
--org string              Organisation ID (overrides saved config)
--project string          Project ID (overrides saved config)
--format string           Output format: table (default) or json
-v, --verbose             Enable verbose logging to console

docs.title: Output Formatting
docs.text:
The CLI supports different output formats using the --format flag:

# Output in JSON format
hc registry list --format=json

# Output in table format (default)
hc registry list --format=table

docs.title: Support
docs.text:
• Report bugs or feature requests in our issue tracker
  • Documentation: Harness Developer Hub

docs.text: MIT License - see LICENSE for details.

docs.title: Documentation Generation Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to generate and maintain documentation for the Harness CLI.

docs.title: Automated Documentation Generation
docs.text: The Harness CLI uses Cobra's built-in documentation generation to automatically create documentation from command definitions.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Generate all documentation formats:

make docs

This will generate: - Markdown files in docs/markdown/ - For websites and GitHub - Man pages in docs/man/ - For Unix/Linux systems - YAML files in docs/yaml/ - Structured data format

docs.title: Manual Generation
docs.text:
You can also run the documentation generator directly:

go run cmd/hc/gendocs.go

docs.title: 1. Markdown Documentation
docs.text:
Generated in docs/markdown/ directory. Perfect for: - GitHub documentation - Static site generators (Hugo, Jekyll, MkDocs) - README files

Usage: 

# View in browser or editor
cat docs/markdown/hc.md

docs.title: 2. Man Pages
docs.text:
Generated in docs/man/ directory. Standard Unix manual pages.

Installation: 

# Install man pages system-wide
sudo cp docs/man/*.1 /usr/local/share/man/man1/

# View man page
man hc
man hc-auth-login

docs.title: 3. YAML Documentation
docs.text: Generated in docs/yaml/ directory. Machine-readable format for: - API documentation tools - Custom documentation generators - Integration with other systems

docs.title: When to Regenerate
docs.text: Run make docs whenever you: 1. Add new commands or subcommands 2. Change command descriptions, flags, or arguments 3. Update help text in any command 4. Modify command structure

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Update Command Descriptions: Keep Short and Long descriptions in your Cobra commands clear and helpful 

    cmd := &cobra.Command{
    Use:   "mycommand",
    Short: "Brief one-line description",
    Long:  `Detailed multi-line description with examples`,
}

  2. Document Flags: Add clear descriptions to all flags 

    cmd.Flags().StringVar(&name, "name", "", "Name of the resource (required)")

  3. Add Examples: Include examples in the command's Example field 

    cmd.Example = `  # Example 1
  hc mycommand --flag value

  # Example 2
  hc mycommand --another-flag`

  4. Regenerate Before Releases: Always regenerate docs before creating a release

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
Add to your .github/workflows/docs.yml:

name: Generate Documentation

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:

jobs:
  docs:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Set up Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v4
        with:
          go-version: '1.24'

      - name: Generate documentation
        run: make docs

      - name: Check for changes
        run: |
          git diff --exit-code docs/ || \
          (echo "Documentation is out of date. Run 'make docs'" && exit 1)

docs.title: Option 1: Cobra Doc Generator (Current)
docs.text:
Pros: - Built into Cobra - Zero configuration - Multiple output formats - Always in sync with code

Cons: - Basic styling - Limited customization

docs.title: Option 2: MkDocs with mkdocs-material
docs.text:
For a beautiful documentation website:

# Install
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Create mkdocs.yml
cat > mkdocs.yml <<EOF
site_name: Harness CLI
theme:
  name: material
  features:
    - navigation.tabs
    - navigation.sections

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - Commands:
    - hc: markdown/hc.md
    - Auth: markdown/hc_auth.md
    - Registry: markdown/hc_registry.md
    - Artifact: markdown/hc_artifact.md
EOF

# Serve locally
mkdocs serve

# Build static site
mkdocs build

docs.title: Option 3: Docusaurus
docs.text:
For a React-based documentation site:

npx create-docusaurus@latest docs-site classic
# Copy markdown files to docs-site/docs/
# Configure docusaurus.config.js
npm start

docs.title: Option 4: GitBook
docs.text: For a hosted documentation platform: - Import your GitHub repository - GitBook automatically renders markdown files - Provides search, versioning, and collaboration features

docs.title: Custom Documentation
docs.text:
The manually created documentation in docs/ provides: - Enhanced formatting and styling - Additional context and tutorials - Usage examples and best practices - Links to external resources

To maintain both: 1. Use make docs for auto-generated reference docs 2. Keep custom guides in docs/ root 3. Link between them as needed

docs.title: Documentation Structure
docs.text:
docs/
├── index.md                    # Main documentation index (custom)
├── examples.md                 # Usage examples (custom)
├── DOCUMENTATION.md            # This file (custom)
├── markdown/                   # Auto-generated markdown
│   ├── hc.md
│   ├── hc_auth.md
│   ├── hc_auth_login.md
│   └── ...
├── man/                        # Auto-generated man pages
│   ├── hc.1
│   ├── hc-auth.1
│   └── ...
└── yaml/                       # Auto-generated YAML
    ├── hc.yaml
    ├── hc_auth.yaml
    └── ...

docs.title: Missing Dependencies
docs.text:
If you see errors about missing packages:

go get github.com/spf13/cobra/doc
go mod tidy

docs.title: Documentation Not Updating
docs.text:
1. Ensure you've saved all code changes
  2. Run make docs again
  3. Check that command definitions are correct

docs.title: Man Pages Not Installing
docs.text:
# Check man page directories
man -w

# Try alternative location
sudo cp docs/man/*.1 /usr/share/man/man1/
sudo mandb  # Update man database

docs.title: Enhancing Command Documentation
docs.text: This guide shows how to improve auto-generated documentation by enhancing your Cobra command definitions.

docs.title: Adding Examples to Commands
docs.text: Add the Example field to your command definition:

docs.title: Before (Basic)
docs.text:
cmd := &cobra.Command{
    Use:   "generic <registry_name> <package_file_path>",
    Short: "Push Generic Artifacts",
    Long:  "Push Generic Artifacts to Harness Artifact Registry",
    Args:  cobra.ExactArgs(2),
    RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
        // implementation
    },
}

docs.title: After (With Examples)
docs.text:
cmd := &cobra.Command{
    Use:   "generic <registry_name> <package_file_path>",
    Short: "Push Generic Artifacts",
    Long: `Push Generic Artifacts to Harness Artifact Registry.

Generic artifacts can be any file type - binaries, archives, configuration 
files, or any other file you want to store and version.`,

    Example: `  # Push a tarball with basic options
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./app.tar.gz \
    --name my-app \
    --version 1.0.0 \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

  # Push with custom filename and description
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./build/output.zip \
    --name my-build \
    --version 2.1.0 \
    --filename release.zip \
    --description "Production release" \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

  # Push configuration file with custom path
  hc artifact push generic config-registry ./config.yaml \
    --name app-config \
    --version 1.0.0 \
    --path configs/production.yaml \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io`,

    Args:  cobra.ExactArgs(2),
    RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
        // implementation
    },
}

docs.title: Adding Global Flags to Commands
docs.text: To show global flags in command documentation, you need to mark them as inherited.

docs.title: Option 1: Use PersistentFlags on Root Command
docs.text:
In your root command (cmd/hc/main.go), flags added with PersistentFlags() automatically appear in all subcommands:

// In main.go
rootCmd.PersistentFlags().StringVar(&config.Global.APIBaseURL, "api-url", "",
    "Base URL for the API (overrides saved config)")
rootCmd.PersistentFlags().StringVar(&config.Global.AuthToken, "token", "",
    "Authentication token (overrides saved config)")
// etc...

These will automatically show in all subcommand documentation under "Options inherited from parent commands".

docs.title: Option 2: Document Global Flags in Long Description
docs.text:
Add global flags info to the Long description:

cmd := &cobra.Command{
    Use:   "list",
    Short: "List all registries",
    Long: `Lists all Harness Artifact Registries in your account, organization, or project scope.

The command displays registry information including identifier, package type, size, 
registry type, description, and URL.

Global Flags:
  All commands support these global flags:
  --account string    Account ID (overrides saved config)
  --api-url string    Base URL for the API
  --token string      Authentication token
  --org string        Organisation ID
  --project string    Project ID
  --format string     Output format: table or json (default: table)
  -v, --verbose       Enable verbose logging`,

    RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
        // implementation
    },
}

docs.title: Complete Example: Enhanced Command
docs.text:
Here's a complete example showing all best practices:

func NewPushGenericCmd(c *cmdutils.Factory) *cobra.Command {
    var packageName, filename, packageVersion, description, path string
    var pkgURL string

    cmd := &cobra.Command{
        Use:   "generic <registry_name> <package_file_path>",
        Short: "Push generic artifacts to registry",

        Long: `Push generic artifacts to Harness Artifact Registry.

Generic artifacts can be any file type - binaries, archives, configuration 
files, or any other file you want to store and version. The CLI uploads the 
file with progress tracking and stores it with the specified name and version.

Arguments:
  registry_name       Name of the registry to push to
  package_file_path   Path to the file to upload

The command validates the file exists, uploads it with progress tracking,
and confirms successful upload with metadata.`,

        Example: `  # Basic upload
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./app.tar.gz \
    --name my-app \
    --version 1.0.0 \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

  # Upload with custom filename
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./build/output.zip \
    --name my-build \
    --version 2.1.0 \
    --filename release.zip \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

  # Upload configuration with custom path
  hc artifact push generic config-registry ./config.yaml \
    --name app-config \
    --version 1.0.0 \
    --path configs/production.yaml \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

  # Upload with description
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./app.tar.gz \
    --name my-app \
    --version 1.0.0 \
    --description "Production release v1.0.0" \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io`,

        Args: cobra.ExactArgs(2),

        PreRun: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) {
            config.Global.Registry.PkgURL = pkgURL
        },

        RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
            // implementation
            return nil
        },
    }

    // Add flags with clear descriptions
    cmd.Flags().StringVarP(&packageName, "name", "n", "", 
        "Name for the artifact (required)")
    cmd.Flags().StringVar(&filename, "filename", "",
        "Name of the file being uploaded (defaults to actual filename)")
    cmd.Flags().StringVar(&packageVersion, "version", "", 
        "Version for the artifact (defaults to '1.0.0')")
    cmd.Flags().StringVarP(&description, "description", "d", "", 
        "Description of the artifact")
    cmd.Flags().StringVar(&path, "path", "", 
        "File path within the package (defaults to filename)")
    cmd.Flags().StringVar(&pkgURL, "pkg-url", "", 
        "Base URL for the Packages API (required)")

    // Mark required flags
    cmd.MarkFlagRequired("pkg-url")
    cmd.MarkFlagRequired("name")

    return cmd
}

docs.title: Before (Basic)
docs.text:
cmd.Flags().StringVar(&name, "name", "", "name")
cmd.Flags().StringVar(&version, "version", "", "version")

docs.title: After (Descriptive)
docs.text:
cmd.Flags().StringVarP(&name, "name", "n", "", 
    "Name for the artifact (required)")
cmd.Flags().StringVar(&version, "version", "", 
    "Version for the artifact (defaults to '1.0.0')")
cmd.Flags().StringVar(&description, "description", "", 
    "Description of the artifact (optional)")
cmd.Flags().BoolVar(&force, "force", false, 
    "Force upload without confirmation prompts")

docs.title: Adding Annotations
docs.text:
You can add metadata to commands for better organization:

cmd := &cobra.Command{
    Use:   "push",
    Short: "Push artifacts",
    Annotations: map[string]string{
        "group": "artifact-management",
        "help":  "https://docs.harness.io/cli/artifact-push",
    },
}

docs.title: Validation Messages
docs.text:
Add helpful validation messages:

cmd := &cobra.Command{
    Use:  "delete <artifact-name>",
    Args: cobra.ExactArgs(1),
    RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
        if registry == "" {
            return fmt.Errorf("--registry flag is required")
        }
        // implementation
    },
}

docs.title: After Making Changes
docs.text:
1. Regenerate documentation: 

    make docs

  2. View updated docs: 

    make docs-serve

  3. Check the changes:

  4. Examples now appear in command documentation
  5. Better descriptions for all flags
  6. More helpful Long descriptions

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use field - Always add examples for complex commands
  2. Long field - Provide detailed explanation with context
  3. Short field - Keep it to one line, under 80 characters
  4. Flag descriptions - Be specific about what each flag does
  5. Mark required flags - Use MarkFlagRequired()
  6. Use shorthand flags - Add -n for --name with StringVarP()
  7. Document defaults - Mention default values in descriptions
  8. Add validation - Return helpful error messages

docs.title: Example Commands to Update
docs.text:
Here are the commands that would benefit most from examples:

  1. Authentication commands (cmd/auth/)
  2. login.go - Add interactive vs non-interactive examples

  3. status.go - Show example output

  4. Registry commands (cmd/registry/command/)

  5. list.go - Add filtering examples

  6. migrate_cmd.go - Add migration config examples

  7. Artifact commands (cmd/artifact/command/)

  8. All push_*.go files - Add package-specific examples
  9. pull.go - Add download examples
  10. delete.go - Show version-specific deletion

docs.title: Testing Your Changes
docs.text:
After updating commands:

# 1. Test the command still works
go run cmd/hc/main.go artifact push generic --help

# 2. Regenerate docs
make docs

# 3. View in browser
make docs-serve

# 4. Check the generated markdown
cat docs/markdown/hc_artifact_push_generic.md

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
Your auto-generated documentation will now include: - ✅ Examples directly in each command page - ✅ Better descriptions and context - ✅ Clear flag documentation - ✅ Helpful usage information - ✅ Global flags shown as inherited options

This makes the documentation much more useful without maintaining separate example files!

docs.title: What We've Created
docs.text: Your Harness CLI now has two types of documentation:

docs.title: 1. Manual Documentation (Current)
docs.text:
High-quality, hand-crafted documentation with: - ✅ Enhanced examples and use cases - ✅ CI/CD integration guides - ✅ Troubleshooting tips - ✅ Best practices

Location: docs/*.md files

docs.title: 2. Automated Documentation (Recommended for Future)
docs.text:
Auto-generated from your Cobra command definitions: - ✅ Always in sync with code - ✅ Zero maintenance overhead - ✅ Multiple output formats (Markdown, Man pages, YAML) - ✅ One command to regenerate everything

Location: docs/markdown/, docs/man/, docs/yaml/

docs.title: Step 1: Install Dependencies
docs.text:
# Add the cobra doc package
go get github.com/spf13/cobra/doc@v1.9.1
go mod tidy

docs.title: Step 2: Generate Documentation
docs.text:
# Generate all documentation formats
make docs

This creates: - Markdown → docs/markdown/*.md (for websites) - Man pages → docs/man/*.1 (for Unix systems) - YAML → docs/yaml/*.yaml (for tooling)

docs.title: Step 3: View Generated Docs
docs.text:
# View markdown
cat docs/markdown/hc.md

# Install and view man pages
sudo cp docs/man/*.1 /usr/local/share/man/man1/
man hc

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: The cmd/hc/gendocs.go file: 1. Imports all your CLI commands 2. Uses Cobra's built-in doc generator 3. Outputs documentation in multiple formats 4. Runs via make docs command

docs.title: When You Add/Modify Commands
docs.text:
# 1. Update your command code
vim cmd/artifact/command/new_command.go

# 2. Regenerate documentation
make docs

# 3. Commit both code and docs
git add cmd/ docs/
git commit -m "Add new command with documentation"

docs.title: Enhancing Command Documentation
docs.text:
Improve auto-generated docs by enhancing your command definitions:

cmd := &cobra.Command{
    Use:   "mycommand <arg>",
    Short: "Brief one-line description",  // Shows in command lists
    Long: `Detailed multi-line description.

This command does X, Y, and Z. It's useful for...`,  // Shows in --help

    Example: `  # Example 1: Basic usage
  hc mycommand value

  # Example 2: With flags
  hc mycommand value --flag option`,  // Shows examples

    Args: cobra.ExactArgs(1),  // Validates arguments
}

// Document your flags clearly
cmd.Flags().StringVar(&name, "name", "", "Name of the resource (required)")
cmd.Flags().BoolVar(&force, "force", false, "Force the operation without confirmation")

docs.title: Comparison: Manual vs Automated
docs.text: Aspect Manual Docs Automated Docs Accuracy Can become outdated Always current Maintenance High effort Zero effort Customization Full control Limited styling Examples Rich examples Basic examples Best for Guides, tutorials Command reference

docs.title: Recommended Approach
docs.text:
Use both!

  1. Automated docs for command reference
  2. Run make docs before each release
  3. Commit generated files to git

  4. Use for API documentation

  5. Manual docs for guides

  6. Keep docs/examples.md for tutorials
  7. Maintain docs/index.md as landing page
  8. Add troubleshooting guides as needed

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
Create .github/workflows/docs.yml:

name: Documentation

on:
  push:
    branches: [main, v2]
  pull_request:

jobs:
  check-docs:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Set up Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v4
        with:
          go-version: '1.24'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          go get github.com/spf13/cobra/doc@v1.9.1
          go mod download

      - name: Generate documentation
        run: make docs

      - name: Check if docs are up to date
        run: |
          if ! git diff --exit-code docs/; then
            echo "❌ Documentation is out of date!"
            echo "Run 'make docs' and commit the changes"
            exit 1
          fi
          echo "✅ Documentation is up to date"

docs.title: Option 1: GitHub Pages
docs.text:
# Use docs/ directory as GitHub Pages source
# Settings → Pages → Source: main branch /docs folder

docs.title: Option 2: MkDocs
docs.text:
# Install MkDocs
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Create configuration
cat > mkdocs.yml <<EOF
site_name: Harness CLI
theme:
  name: material
docs_dir: docs
EOF

# Serve locally
mkdocs serve

# Deploy to GitHub Pages
mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: Option 3: Docusaurus
docs.text:
# Create Docusaurus site
npx create-docusaurus@latest website classic

# Copy docs
cp -r docs/ website/docs/

# Serve
cd website && npm start

docs.title: "Missing package" errors
docs.text:
go get github.com/spf13/cobra/doc@v1.9.1
go mod tidy

docs.title: Documentation not updating
docs.text:
# Clean and regenerate
rm -rf docs/markdown docs/man docs/yaml
make docs

docs.title: Man pages not working
docs.text:
# Check man path
man -w

# Try alternative location
sudo cp docs/man/*.1 /usr/share/man/man1/
sudo mandb

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
1. Install dependencies: go get github.com/spf13/cobra/doc@v1.9.1
  2. Generate docs: make docs
  3. Review output: Check docs/markdown/ directory
  4. Commit: Add generated docs to version control
  5. Automate: Set up CI/CD to verify docs are current

docs.title: Web Documentation Guide
docs.text: Generate beautiful web documentation for your Harness CLI using various tools.

docs.title: Why MkDocs?
docs.text:
• ✅ Beautiful, modern design
  • ✅ Built-in search
  • ✅ Mobile responsive
  • ✅ Dark/light mode
  • ✅ Easy to deploy
  • ✅ No build step needed

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Install MkDocs and Material theme
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Or use pipx for isolated installation
pipx install mkdocs
pipx inject mkdocs mkdocs-material

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Serve locally (with live reload)
mkdocs serve

# Open browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000

# Build static site
mkdocs build

# Output will be in site/ directory

docs.title: Deploy to GitHub Pages
docs.text:
# One command deployment
mkdocs gh-deploy

# This builds and pushes to gh-pages branch
# Enable GitHub Pages in repo settings

docs.title: Customize
docs.text: Edit mkdocs.yml to: - Change colors and theme - Add/remove navigation items - Configure search - Add custom CSS/JavaScript

docs.title: Why Docusaurus?
docs.text:
• ✅ Modern React-based
  • ✅ Versioning support
  • ✅ i18n (internationalization)
  • ✅ Plugin ecosystem
  • ✅ Used by Facebook, Meta

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Create Docusaurus site
npx create-docusaurus@latest website classic

cd website

# Install dependencies
npm install

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
# Copy documentation
cp -r ../docs ./docs/

# Edit docusaurus.config.js
# Update title, tagline, URLs, etc.

# Start dev server
npm start

# Build for production
npm run build

# Serve production build
npm run serve

docs.title: Deploy
docs.text:
# Deploy to GitHub Pages
GIT_USER=<your-username> npm run deploy

# Or use Vercel/Netlify
# Just connect your repo and deploy

docs.title: Why Docsify?
docs.text:
• ✅ No build step
  • ✅ Single HTML file
  • ✅ Instant setup
  • ✅ Lightweight

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Install globally
npm i docsify-cli -g

# Or use npx (no install needed)
npx docsify-cli init ./docs

docs.title: Create index.html
docs.text:
Create docs/index.html:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Harness CLI Documentation</title>
  <meta name="description" content="Harness CLI Documentation">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/docsify@4/lib/themes/vue.css">
</head>
<body>
  <div id="app"></div>
  <script>
    window.$docsify = {
      name: 'Harness CLI',
      repo: 'harness/harness-cli',
      loadSidebar: true,
      subMaxLevel: 3,
      search: 'auto',
      copyCode: {
        buttonText : 'Copy',
        errorText  : 'Error',
        successText: 'Copied'
      }
    }
  </script>
  <script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/docsify@4"></script>
  <script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/docsify/lib/plugins/search.min.js"></script>
  <script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/docsify-copy-code"></script>
  <script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/prismjs@1/components/prism-bash.min.js"></script>
  <script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/prismjs@1/components/prism-go.min.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Serve locally
docsify serve docs

# Or with npx

docs.title: GitHub Actions for MkDocs
docs.text:
Create .github/workflows/docs.yml:

name: Deploy Documentation

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Setup Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: 3.x

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        run: mkdocs gh-deploy --force

docs.title: Quick Start: Web Documentation
docs.text: Get your documentation website running in 2 minutes!

docs.title: Step 1: Install MkDocs
docs.text:
# Using pip
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Or using pipx (recommended for isolated install)
pipx install mkdocs
pipx inject mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Or using Homebrew (macOS)
brew install mkdocs
pip install mkdocs-material

docs.title: Step 2: Serve Locally
docs.text:
# Option 1: Using Make
make docs-serve

# Option 2: Direct command
mkdocs serve

Open your browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000 🎉

docs.title: Step 3: Preview Your Docs
docs.text: You should see: - ✅ Beautiful Material Design theme - ✅ Dark/Light mode toggle - ✅ Search functionality - ✅ Mobile responsive - ✅ All your command documentation - ✅ Live reload (changes update automatically)

docs.title: Step 4: Deploy to GitHub Pages
docs.text:
# Option 1: Using Make
make docs-deploy

# Option 2: Direct command
mkdocs gh-deploy

Then enable GitHub Pages in your repository settings: 1. Go to Settings → Pages 2. Source should be set to gh-pages branch 3. Your docs will be live at: https://harness.github.io/harness-cli/

docs.title: That's It! 🚀
docs.text: Your documentation is now: - ✅ Auto-generated from your CLI commands - ✅ Beautifully styled with Material Design - ✅ Searchable - ✅ Deployed to the web

make docs              # Generate markdown docs from CLI
make docs-serve        # Start local web server

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
name: Push Artifact

on:
  push:
    tags:
      - 'v*'

jobs:
  push-artifact:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Install Harness CLI
        run: |
          curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/harness/harness-cli/v2/install | sh
          sudo mv hc /usr/local/bin/

      - name: Login to Harness
        env:
          HARNESS_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.HARNESS_API_KEY }}
          HARNESS_API_URL: ${{ secrets.HARNESS_API_URL }}
        run: hc auth status

      - name: Build artifact
        run: make build

      - name: Push to Harness Registry
        env:
          PKG_URL: ${{ secrets.HARNESS_PKG_URL }}
        run: |
          VERSION=${GITHUB_REF#refs/tags/v}
          hc artifact push generic my-registry ./build/app.tar.gz \
            --name my-app \
            --version $VERSION \
            --pkg-url $PKG_URL

docs.title: GitLab CI
docs.text:
push-artifact:
  stage: deploy
  image: alpine:latest
  before_script:
    - apk add --no-cache curl
    - curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/harness/harness-cli/v2/install | sh
    - mv hc /usr/local/bin/
  script:
    - hc auth login --api-token $HARNESS_API_KEY --account $HARNESS_ACCOUNT --non-interactive
    - hc artifact push generic my-registry ./build/app.tar.gz 
        --name my-app 
        --version $CI_COMMIT_TAG 
        --pkg-url $HARNESS_PKG_URL
  only:
    - tags

docs.title: Jenkins Pipeline
docs.text:
pipeline {
    agent any

    environment {
        HARNESS_API_KEY = credentials('harness-api-key')
        HARNESS_PKG_URL = credentials('harness-pkg-url')
    }

    stages {
        stage('Install CLI') {
            steps {
                sh 'curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/harness/harness-cli/v2/install | sh'
            }
        }

        stage('Push Artifact') {
            steps {
                sh '''
                    hc auth login --api-token $HARNESS_API_KEY --account abc123 --non-interactive
                    hc artifact push generic my-registry ./build/app.tar.gz \
                        --name my-app \
                        --version ${BUILD_NUMBER} \
                        --pkg-url $HARNESS_PKG_URL
                '''
            }
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Bash Script: Bulk Upload
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# Upload multiple artifacts from a directory

REGISTRY="my-registry"
PKG_URL="https://pkg.harness.io"
VERSION="1.0.0"

for file in ./artifacts/*; do
    filename=$(basename "$file")
    echo "Uploading $filename..."

    hc artifact push generic "$REGISTRY" "$file" \
        --name "${filename%.*}" \
        --version "$VERSION" \
        --filename "$filename" \
        --pkg-url "$PKG_URL"
done

echo "✓ All artifacts uploaded"

docs.title: Python Script: List and Filter
docs.text:
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import json
import subprocess

def get_artifacts(registry=None):
    """Get artifacts from Harness registry"""
    cmd = ["hc", "artifact", "list", "--format", "json"]
    if registry:
        cmd.extend(["--registry", registry])

    result = subprocess.run(cmd, capture_output=True, text=True)
    return json.loads(result.stdout)

def filter_by_package_type(artifacts, package_type):
    """Filter artifacts by package type"""
    return [a for a in artifacts if a.get("packageType") == package_type]

# Get all Docker artifacts
artifacts = get_artifacts()
docker_artifacts = filter_by_package_type(artifacts, "DOCKER")

print(f"Found {len(docker_artifacts)} Docker artifacts:")
for artifact in docker_artifacts:
    print(f"  - {artifact['name']} v{artifact['version']}")

docs.title: Using Multiple Accounts
docs.text:

$ hc auth login --account account1 --org org1
$ hc auth logout

docs.title: JSON Output Processing
docs.text:
# Extract specific fields with jq
$ hc registry list --format json | jq -r '.[] | "\(.identifier): \(.packageType)"'

# Count artifacts by type
$ hc artifact list --format json | jq 'group_by(.packageType) | map({type: .[0].packageType, count: length})'

# Get registry URLs
$ hc registry list --format json | jq -r '.[].url'

.PHONY: deploy

deploy: build

docs.title: hc artifact push generic
docs.text: Push generic artifacts to registry

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
Push generic artifacts to Harness Artifact Registry.

Generic artifacts can be any file type - binaries, archives, configuration files, or any other file you want to store and version. The CLI uploads the file with progress tracking and stores it with the specified name and version.

hc artifact push generic <registry_name> <package_file_path> [flags]

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Basic upload
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./app.tar.gz \
    --name my-app \
    --version 1.0.0 \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

  # Upload with custom filename
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./build/output.zip \
    --name my-build \
    --version 2.1.0 \
    --filename release.zip \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

  # Upload with description
  hc artifact push generic my-registry ./app.tar.gz \
    --name my-app \
    --version 1.0.0 \
    --description "Production release" \
    --pkg-url https://pkg.harness.io

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
-d, --description string   Description of the artifact
      --filename string      Name of the file being uploaded (defaults to actual filename)
  -h, --help                 help for generic
  -n, --name string          Name for the artifact (required)
      --path string          File path within the package (defaults to filename)
      --pkg-url string       Base URL for the Packages API (required)
      --version string       Version for the artifact (defaults to '1.0.0')

docs.title: hc registry migrate
docs.text: Start a migration based on configuration

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
Migrate artifacts from a source registry to a Harness Artifact Registry.

This command reads a YAML configuration file that defines the source and destination registries, credentials, and artifact mappings.

Example configuration file (config.yaml):

version: 1.0.0 concurrency: 5 overwrite: false

source: endpoint: https://source-registry.example.com type: JFROG # Supported: JFROG, NEXUS credentials: username: source_user password: source_password insecure: false

destination: endpoint: https://pkg.harness.io type: HAR credentials: username: harness_user password: harness_api_key

mappings: - artifactType: DOCKER sourceRegistry: docker-repo destinationRegistry: harness-docker-repo

- artifactType: MAVEN
  sourceRegistry: maven-releases
  destinationRegistry: harness-maven

- artifactType: NPM
  sourceRegistry: npm-local
  destinationRegistry: harness-npm

- artifactType: HELM
  sourceRegistry: helm-charts
  destinationRegistry: harness-helm

Supported artifact types: DOCKER, HELM, HELM_LEGACY, MAVEN, NPM, NUGET, PYTHON, GO, GENERIC, CONDA, COMPOSER

Environment variables can be used in the config file using ${VAR_NAME} syntax.

Usage example: hc registry migrate -c config.yaml

hc registry migrate [flags]

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
--concurrency int   Number of concurrent operations (overrides config) (default 1)
  -c, --config string     Path to configuration file (default "config.yaml")
  -h, --help              help for migrate
      --overwrite         Allow overwriting artifacts
      --pkg-url string    Base URL for the API (overrides config)

docs.title: Options inherited from parent commands
docs.text:
--account string   Account ID (overrides saved config)
      --api-url string   Base URL for the API (overrides saved config)
      --format string    Output format: table or json (default "table")
      --org string       Organisation ID (overrides saved config)
      --project string   Project ID (overrides saved config)
      --token string     Authentication token (overrides saved config)
  -v, --verbose          Enable verbose logging to console
